newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Mahathir says APEC talks with Australia cordial.
newsitem.headline: Mahathir says APEC talks with Australia cordial.

text.p: Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad said on Saturday he held friendly talks with his Australian counterpart John Howard and neither man brought up the potentially explosive racism debate in Australia.
Mahathir told reporters after his 45-minute talk with Howard on the sidelines of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) conference that they had exchanged views on Asia-Pacific trade issues.
He said a racism row in Australia, sparked by maverick politician Pauline Hanson, did not come up in their talks.
In Sydney, more than 5,000 people turned out for a rally on Saturday against racism, joined by a coalition of mainly Asian ethnic groups, and marched to the prime minister's office.
Howard has been accused of not taking a strong enough stand against Hanson, whose views against Asian immigration and aboriginal welfare have struck a chord with voters.
Howard has consistentLy spoken against calls for a racially based immigration policy, but has been reluctant to reply directly to what he has termed the views of one legislator.
His stance has been criticised in Asian newspapers and has begun to intrude on Canberra's relations with the region.
On Thursday, Malaysian Foreign Minister Abdullah Badawi raised the issue with his Australian counterpart, Alexander Downer, in the Philippine capital ahead of Monday's APEC summit.
Mahathir said Howard had accepted an invitation to visit Malaysia next year.
